Hilbert spaces

Let D\mathcal{D}D be the space of analytic functions f(z)f\p{z}f(z) on the unit disc D={z∣∣z∣<1}\D = \set{z \mid \abs{z} < 1}D={z∣∣z∣<1} such that f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0 and ∫D∣f′(z)∣2 dx dy<∞\int_\D \abs{f'\p{z}}^2 \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} < \infty∫D​∣f′(z)∣2dxdy<∞.

  1. Prove that D\mathcal{D}D is complete in the norm

    ∥f∥=(∫D∣f′(z)∣ dx dy)1/2.\norm{f} = \p{\int_\D \abs{f'\p{z}} \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y}}^{1/2}.∥f∥=(∫D​∣f′(z)∣dxdy)1/2.

  2. Give a necessary and sufficient condition on the coefficients ana_nan​ for the function f(z)=∑n≥1anznf\p{z} = \sum_{n\geq1} a_n z^nf(z)=∑n≥1​an​zn to belong to D\mathcal{D}D.
Solution.

  1. Let {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ be Cauchy in D\mathcal{D}D. Notice by the mean value property, {fn′}n\set{f_n'}_n{fn′​}n​ is uniformly bounded on compact sets, i.e., {fn′}n\set{f_n'}_n{fn′​}n​ is a normal family. Hence, fn′→gf_n' \to gfn′​→g locally uniformly in D\DD for some holomorphic ggg on D\DD.

    Let f(z)=∫0zg(w) dwf\p{z} = \int_0^z g\p{w} \,\diff{w}f(z)=∫0z​g(w)dw, where integration is done on the segment [0,z]\br{0, z}[0,z]. Then f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0 by construction and

    ∣fn(z)−f(z)∣≤∫0z∣fn′(w)−f(w)∣ dw,\abs{f_n\p{z} - f\p{z}} \leq \int_0^z \abs{f_n'\p{w} - f\p{w}} \,\diff{w},∣fn​(z)−f(z)∣≤∫0z​∣fn′​(w)−f(w)∣dw,

    so fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f locally uniformly as well. Thus, we see that fn(0)→f(0)f_n\p{0} \to f\p{0}fn​(0)→f(0) and fn′f_n'fn′​ converges locally uniformly to ggg, so fnf_nfn​ converges locally uniformly to fff with f′=gf' = gf′=g. By Fatou's lemma, we also see that ∥f∥≤sup⁡n∥fn∥<∞\norm{f} \leq \sup_n \norm{f_n} < \infty∥f∥≤supn​∥fn​∥<∞, since {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is Cauchy, so D\mathcal{D}D is complete.

  2. First, suppose that fff is holomorphic in D\DD with f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0. We may then write f(z)=∑n=1∞anznf\p{z} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n z^nf(z)=∑n=1∞​an​zn. Then because its Taylor series converges locally uniformly,

    ∥f∥2=∫D∣f′(z)∣2 dx dy=∫D(∑n=1∞nanzn−1)(∑m=1∞mamzm−1)‾ dx dy=∫01r∫02π(∑n=1∞nanrn−1ei(n−1)θ)(∑m=1∞mamrm−1ei(m−1)θ)‾ dθ dr=∑n=0∞2π∫01n2∣an∣2r2n−1 dr=2π∑n=0∞n∣an∣2.\begin{aligned} \norm{f}^2 &= \int_\D \abs{f'\p{z}}^2 \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} \\ &= \int_\D \p{\sum_{n=1}^\infty na_n z^{n-1}} \conj{\p{\sum_{m=1}^\infty ma_m z^{m-1}}} \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} \\ &= \int_0^1 r \int_0^{2\pi} \p{\sum_{n=1}^\infty na_n r^{n-1} e^{i\p{n-1}\theta}} \conj{\p{\sum_{m=1}^\infty ma_m r^{m-1} e^{i\p{m-1}\theta}}} \,\diff{\theta} \,\diff{r} \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty 2\pi \int_0^1 n^2\abs{a_n}^2 r^{2n-1} \,\diff{r} \\ &= 2\pi \sum_{n=0}^\infty n\abs{a_n}^2. \end{aligned}∥f∥2​=∫D​∣f′(z)∣2dxdy=∫D​(n=1∑∞​nan​zn−1)(m=1∑∞​mam​zm−1)​dxdy=∫01​r∫02π​(n=1∑∞​nan​rn−1ei(n−1)θ)(m=1∑∞​mam​rm−1ei(m−1)θ)​dθdr=n=0∑∞​2π∫01​n2∣an​∣2r2n−1dr=2πn=0∑∞​n∣an​∣2.​

    Thus, f∈Df \in \mathcal{D}f∈D if and only if a0=0a_0 = 0a0​=0 and ∑n=0∞n∣an∣2<∞\sum_{n=0}^\infty n\abs{a_n}^2 < \infty∑n=0∞​n∣an​∣2<∞.
